title: Is the sentence 'It's its.' grammatically correct? - Quora

response.answer_text: Well, sort of. I'm sorry, I know that's terribly vague, so I'll try to clarify a little bit. The sentence, “It’s its.” conveys the meaning, “it belongs to it,” albeit in a nonconventional way. While the sentence is technically grammatically correct, there's a few problems with it. First, let's break it down into its sections. “It's” is just a contraction for “it is,” so we'll look at it that way for simplicity: It is its. Here,“It” is a pronoun and the subject of the sentence, “is” is the verb of the sentence, and “its” is a possessive pronoun that the verb relates to the subject. Structurally sound. An example of a similarly structured sentence would be, “I'm yours.” The only difference is which personal pronoun is used. So, structurally, the sentence is grammatically correct. However, there are still a few issues with it. First, “its” is not generally used as a possessive pronoun in English, mainly because things we call “it” generally aren't considered to be owners. So while a book might be mine, yours, or his, it's probably not its. Another reason for this is that the pronoun “it” can cover such a wide range of objects, so it's often more practical to use a specific possessive. Instead of saying “the book is its,” where “it" refers to a library, one might say, to avoid ambiguity, “the book is the library's.” Because of this, it's awkward to use “its” as a possessive pronoun, such as in your sentence. Note that this is not to be confused with the widespread use of “its” as a possessive determiner, which is totally normal usage. The odd times when it is okay to use “its” as a possessive pronoun happen when there are enough context clues to make it clear what is being said. Your example sentence has really no context clues. Another problem with your sentence is that because of the ambiguity of the word “it,” when it refers to a noun, it's important that the noun is clarified so there's not ambiguity in the meaning. Your sentence uses “it” twice, first as a subject personal pronoun, then as a possessive pronoun. With no promises referent in the sentence, it's assumed you're referring to something in a previous sentence. The problem is that both instances of “it” have the same referent. An example of another sentence like this would be “He’s his.” It's grammatically correct, yes, but it doesn't quite make sense. The implied meaning of your sentence is: [referent noun A] is [possessed by [referent noun A]]. This same idea can be expressed with much less ambiguity, and less awkward phrasing, with the sentence, “It belongs to itself.” Of course, if you just like the sound of “It’s its,” and don't care about how understandable it is, then yes, it is grammatically correct. And it makes a whole lot more sense than the (also grammatically correct) “Buffalo buffalo Buffalo buffalo buffalo buffalo Buffalo buffalo.”

My answer is that it is grammatically correct. And that’s your answer. Now if “it” is gender neutral here, then that’s perfectly fine to use. If “it” has a gender, then it’s preferable to use the gender instead just for clarification. Then, there’s two ‘it’s. The first is indicating one object and the second one is indicating another. So essentially, object one is possessed/owned by object two. Overall the sentence makes sense and in casual/normal conversations it can be understood, but they may ask you to clarify what is the object that possesses the item. Examples: It’s its, can be replaced with “That ball is the dog’s”, but do keep in mind dogs also have genders, but animals can also be referred to as ‘it’. It’s its, could be replaced with, “That [tyre] is the truck’s [tyre].”

Yes, it is. As a whole sentence, it’s its is just as correct as it’s yours, it’s ours, it’s hers, it’s his and it’s theirs, but it lacks the elegance of, for example, it’s his, and it would be more likely used as part of a sentence. As part of a sentence, the possessive its would be followed by whatever it is that belongs to it. For example: “Is that part of the car’s wheel lying on the road?” “Yes, it’s its hubcap.”

Is the sentence "It's its." grammatically correct? This sentence occupies a sort of twilight zone bounded by four categories: correct, incorrect, vague, and clumsy. I can see that this sentence could be correct, but I can only imagine one situation in which it would not be vague or clumsy, and that is as an answer to a question about grammar: Which is correct, “This book has a typographical error on it’s title page” or “This book has a typographical error on its title page”? It’s its.

Technically correct, as in “it’s hers” or “it’s ours”, but it’s not used, probably because it sounds repetitive and obscure (e.g. can be construed as “its its”). Also, “its” is a different case for “it’s its” and “it’s its thing”: the former is a possessive pronoun, and the latter is a possessive determiner.

The sentence is grammatically correct. It means: It is its. That is to say it is a quotation one might hear (or see written in text) when explanation is given about the often seen pitfall of many in English about the correct use of its as a possessive pronoun, whereas it’s is the contraction of it is. Confusion stems from the fact that in English the possessive case is normally formed by the addition of ‘s to most singular nouns.

I might use the sentence thus: What is the correct possessive of ““it?” It’s its.
